p: In experimental studies using the ferret-CDV model, it was shown that the H protein is a key determinant of virus interaction with CD150, and that variations in this protein may influence tissue tropism [ 70, 72, 73]. Molecular evolution studies of CDV isolates from non-canine carnivores indicate that variation at a small number of key H protein residues involved in binding to CD150 may drive CDV adaptation to new hosts [ 74]. Although the H-protein sequence is overall not well conserved, two clusters of H amino acid residues involved in CD150 attachment (positions 526–529 and 547–548 and amino acid 552) are highly conserved and possibly facilitate overlapping host ranges between PDV and CDV [ 43, 63, 73].
